column2: Local polities are states that have arisen from disunited tribes and confederations or have slipped out of the grasps of larger realms. Often considered nothing more than petty states with squabbling tyrants whose authority barely extends beyond the walls of their citadels, they lack the courtly grandeur and the ability to administer more than their local communities.

Regional Authorities are the kingdoms and regional powers that are below the prominence of a hegemon but are potent enough powers in their own locale. Monarchs rely on landed military aristocrats and a growing palace structure. This represent the united polity of a people as well as their subjugated neighbors.

Hegemonic Powers are large realms stretching from one corner of the world to the next. Monarchs rule a vast cosmopolitan realm of many religions, tribes and cultures with the help of an army of bureaucrats and the aristocracy. The will and fate of all is the ruler's demand and decree. The monarch strides the world of men as a glorious prince, all the peoples of the world will know their name!

Military Governors are of course drawn from the class of military-aristocrats, they govern the surrounding lands from their country estates and city holdings in the name of their liege. Governors may rule for life or at the mercy of their liege, who may repossess the leadership of the territory at a whim and redistribute it to a more worthy commander. Governorates are focused on raising armies of men and chariots for their lord, thus less tax is expected to be paid forward as it is used to outfit the local nobles and levy the urban and rural freemen.

A small, homogenous tribe encompassing the same amount of territory as a city state or minor-warlord. Heirs are chosen from the current ruler's children or siblings either through general confirmation by the ruler or chosen by tribal elders depending on religion and culture. The ruler is usually only behest to the desires of his own tribe and court so the council holds less sway. Locked to duchy and below.

A confederacy allows for a tribal realm to grow larger but also as a natural consequence decentralizes power. The ruler can now be selected from beyond the ruling family and can be drawn from the other tribes and victorious commanders by an electorate of the Council and the tribal vassals. Council laws are locked as well, all decisions must be in agreement with the Council of tribal representatives. The ruler is less an authoritarian monarch and more an arbiter of disputes and leader of armies against outside aggression. There are ways around this, if you centralize and woo the princes of the tribes you can have yourself elected King.

A government in which the realm is wholly occupied on the subject of war. Liege and vassal alike are expected to uphold military values and to keep a large and powerful army, even at the expense of the realm's taxes and stability
The successor of the monarch is chosen by them along among their kin.
The successor of the monarch is chosen by them along among their adult kin.

Military Governors are appointed on the behest of their liege to govern a province or polity, a legal representative of their liege (sometimes even being of kin). They are appointed and thus can be replaced at the whim of their liege.
The government system defines whether the realm relies on the courtly skills of their council or the magistrates of the cities of the realm.

Oligarchic States are reliant on their magistrates and local administrators of their realm's cities and provinces. Particularly cunning or shrewd administrators will prefer this form of governance as it is much easier to bypass the will of the Royal Family and Palace Court. The monarch will get a boon in taxes at the expense of their army. They will also be greatly restricted in their capacity to govern outside the palace and are more at the mercy of influential vassals.

The royal court and family are the primary conduit for which the realm is governed. It is understood that the Monarch is a regent of the Divine and and thus their offsprings should succeed them, though that may not always be possible or practical. The warrior-aristocrats and palace scribes in the council greatly favor the strength of their lord. As a result the armies they field, wield a zeal for their liege but provincial lords scoff at the lost of their autonomy and may not be willing to cooperate with their sovereign.
The status afforded to the foreigners that reside in the realm.
Dare we call them people? Dogs befits their stature and character better, and they will know who their masters are.
We placed no significance to the foreigners that reside in our realm and treat them with indifference.
These foreigners are given autonomy in our realm so long as they acknowledge our sovereignty.
The status of tribute received from foreign cultures and faiths
Tributes are asked to contribute a larger share of their coffers for the good of the realm, at the expense of military contributions.
Tributes are asked to contribute their fair share and troops for the good of the realm.
Tributes are asked to contribute a larger share of their armies for the good of the realm, at the expense of tribute tax.

Palatial societies are based entirely upon the central palace and its bureaucracy. The palace complex manages all affairs of the realm, with smaller cities existing to serve it. This system is highly centralized, which lends itself both a rich state and a disgruntled set of vassals.

“Blessed are you, Adonai Eloheinu, King of the universe.”\n\nIt was in the dust of the heathen streets of Ur that Avraham ben Tera heard the voice of the One God. At His command Avraham braved hardship and war leading his household into Canaan, where he received the instructions for the Covenant. Out of his loins will come a great nation it is said, and now the sons of his grandson Yisra'el bin Yitzhak have become an extended family of twelve tribes. Under the leadership of Moshe they defied the Kings of Mizrayim and were instructed by him in the Law. Their priests are usually drawn from the Tribe of Levi, and their duties include ritual animal sacrifice and the smearing of blood in atonement for sins.

The men of Edom are not wholly sons of Kenaan, but are indeed kin to the Yisraelim. These sons of Esau have turned to idolatry and nearly forgotten the covenant of their father Avraham ben Terah. They do however retain the practice of circumcision and name El Shaddai among the gods worthy of veneration. Qos is their patron god, the archer who gleams forth in the desert and hunts his foes like the lion hunts the antelope. Qos is also worshipped by the Nabatu and others of the banu Yishma'el under the name “Quzah”.

The fertile westlands of Kenaan are home to a unique blend of gods and heroes. The creator and gray-haired father of the Elihi is El “The Bull” who rules from his tent atop mount Sappan and instructs his children and servants alongside his consort Asherah. Ba’al Hadaad son of Dagon holds lightning in the palm of his hand and brings the summer rains, in the youth of the world he challenged wicked Yam of the sea and defeated the coiling serpent Litanu. Fiery Molek fumes and demands offerings from his followers and grants them boons of health and herds. Each city and king tends to have a particular patron from among the pantheon.

The traditions and cults of the Amurru, a tall, brash, and ancient people of mountain and pasture. They ruled as Kings and Princes over the Akkadi and Sumeru for 500 years and carried their gods with them on the backs of their furious chariots. The old gods of their forefathers have been preserved outside of Akkadi in the plains and deserts of the westlands. At the head of the host of Hosts is El Amurru, god of the high mountains and desert wind who leads the familiar host of the gods of Kenaan and Akkadi. Belet-Seri is his wife and queen of the desert, and Ba’al Hadad the Thunderer is his regent.

Assur is proclaimed to be the The Lord of All Heaven by the people of his city. For almost a thousand years the people of Assur have believed in the superiority of their god over the southern gods Marduk and Enlil. While the south fell to the half-beast Amurru and Kassu dogs, the sons of Assur preserved their freedom and supremacy. The Sarsarannu rules as regent for Assur and is the supreme authority in secular and eclesiastical matters and must prove his worth to the priesthood in the heat of battle. Assur is the hunter, first among his godly brethren and the slayer of lions and taker of pelts. His enemies should perhaps fear for their own skins...

The Nešili took up the mantle of the peoples they conquered and thereafter called themselves heirs to Hatti. Their gods still have the fierce air of the chariot and the steppe about them, every city and village swears itself to a different god of thunder and celebrates the defeat of the serpent Illuyanka every spring. The Great King of the Hatti is called “Our Sun” by his subjects who believe that his power on earth is drawn from the stormgod Tarhunna and his queen Arinniti of the sun. Tarhunna was of the Nešili, and Arinniti of the Old Hatti. Their marriage symbolized the union of two great nations and reflects the dual ancestry of the inhabitants of Hatti. At his investiture the Sallihassu of Hattussa symbolically marries the Sun and is proclaimed High Priest and Regent of the gods.
§Y*§! Ishalitethai rulers may contact the gods Tarhunna, Arinniti, and Telipinu.\n

The Luwi traditions and gods are kin to their Nešili cousins. Tarhunna the Thunderer brings the summer rains and fattens the kine, and from the haft of his axe hangs great bunches of grapes and vines. Freemen pray to him in their huts for golden grain and friendly weather while princes and chieftains pray in loud shouts to heaven on the fields of a chariot filled battle. Mount Korikos is believed to be the site of the Dracomachy where Tarhunna and Tiwaz the Father-Sun slew the great Serpent to win back Tarhunna’s stolen eyes and heart. The festival of Puruli is held in spring to celebrate the death of the dragon and triumph of the gods.
§Y*§! Haianiluwi rulers may contact the gods Tarhunna, Arinniti, and Telipinu.\n

...and the earth groaned beneath them as at the wrath of Zeus whose joy is in the thunder, when he lasheth the earth about Typhoeus in the country of the Arimoi...” Aegis-bearing Zeus reprimands and punishes his celestial and mortal children with hideous swears and flaming darts of lightning while his jealous seaward brother causes the land to roll and shudder like the waves of the wine-dark sea. The goddesses are just as fearsome as their brothers and husbands. Cow-eyed Here brings both comfort and pain to men and women and Artemis pierces the hearts of woodsmen with silver-tipped arrows of horn.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
pantes_theoi_FEATURES;§Y*§! Pantes Theoi rulers may contact the gods Zeus, Ares, Athenâ, Demeter, Apollon, Hermes, and Aphrodite.\n;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

assussani;Assussani;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
assussani_DESC;Over the briny Aigaios came the wide-ruling gods of the tireless Danaoi. Salt-soaked oars and swift-turning chariot wheels carry the warriors and kings of Assuwa across the land, ever searching for wealth or land to raise up proud well-walled cities and the blood drinking altars of gleaming temples. Theirs is the flashing helm, the stamping horse, and the high white walls of the unbreakable citadels. Gleaming Ziuš quarrels and reprimands his seething sons and daughters who glide down from the high mountain to interfere in the lives and ways of mortal men. Some say the doom of the Asu has already been decided by the gods...;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
assussani_FEATURES;§Y*§! Assussani rulers may contact the gods Zeus, Ares, Athenâ, Demeter, Apollon, Hermes, and Aphrodite.\n;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

european_group;Europes;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

dentudisas;Dentudisas;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
dentudisas_DESC;Thrax’s sons are a ferocious and tempestuous lot, according to some they are the most numerous of all the peoples in the world. The clang of metal, the sweet sound of the war horn and the rattle of the javelin resound throughout the land while the moldering bones of ancient kings lay upon piles of weapons and treasure beneath high burial mounds. Sabázios the fair horseman gallops across the heavens and tramples the serpents under the sharp hooves of his steed. Woe to the enemies of Thrax, for when taken in battle they are almost always offered in sacrifice to battle-glad Pleistoros.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
dentudisas_FEATURES;§Y*§! Dentudisas rulers may contact the gods Sabázios, Pleistoros, and Derzelas.\n;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

doumos;Doumos;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
doumos_FEATURES;§Y*§! Doumos rulers may contact the gods Sabázios and Kubeleya.\n;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

noreligion;The Eternal Darkness;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
noreligion_DESC;PLEASE REPORT THIS IF YOU SEE IT\nFrom the time even before the creation of the World and its Celestial Shroud of Stars and Gods that illuminate, lies the dark expanse of the endless oceans. Everlasting, Unchanging, the embodiment of the Primordial forces of Chaos. Even the so-called Chaos Gods from Apep the Serpent and Tiamat the Winged Mistress fear the deepest shadows of the One that pre-date all. It is said that those that know the name of it were driven to madness, others worship its wicked snarl, but what it most troubling is that it is said that the soil of this world was once consumed in its bosom of sacrilege. Most troubling yet even among the Higher Planes" It is rumored to linger in the shadow of the divine... waiting as it has for since before the spark and when the last light flicker out to take all in its eternal expanse.

column15: x #From Phrygian wit- (to know), and tios (gods)

column2: Rulers can conquer a duchy without any specific reason.
Rulers can conquer single border counties without any specific reason.
Has not conquered in five years
Has not used the Phrugios Invasion Casus Belli thrice
...but the son of Kronos, even Zeus that beareth the aegis, hath brought sorrows upon me, in that he casteth me into the midst of fruitless strifes and wranglings.
Forthwith then he went down from the rugged mount, striding forth with swift footsteps, and the high mountains trembled beneath the immortal feet of Poseidaon as he went.
“Ares, Ares, thou bane of mortals, thou blood-stained stormer of walls, wilt thou not now enter into the battle..."
A hero with the power invested in [This.Founder.GetHerHim] by the gods themselves, their descendants command respect, and their legacy commands adoration.

The authority of the sovereign is determined by how much control over their realm they have. As it ebbs and flows, so does their power.
Imperial authority can be §Gincreased§! by:
§Y*§! Having high attributes or skills
§Y*§! Having loyal councilors
§Y*§! Having a Weak Council
§Y*§! Winning wars
Imperial authority can be §Rdecreased§! by:
§Y*§! Having low attributes or skills
§Y*§! Succession
§Y*§! Long regencies
§Y*§! Having disloyal councilors
§Y*§! Having a Strong Council
§Y*§! Losing wars and major battles
[Root.GetTitledFirstName] has become a bit too influential within the court. If I were to slander [Root.GetHerHim], it may cut [Root.GetHerHim] down to size.
Received Imperial Authority Increase From War
Same Religion as the Founder of this Bloodline
The foreign communities of this province are being oppressed.
The foreign communities of this province have autonomy.
The tribute in this province is tax-focused.
The tribute in this province is levy-focused.
Due to the lack of a native ruler or autonomy, the local people are resistant to your rule...

The bureaucracy of a realm is determined by how much bureaucratic norms are prevalent in said realm. As it changes, the norms of the realm change with it.
Palace bureaucracy can be §Gincreased§! by:
§Y*§! Having qualified lords
§Y*§! Having a powerful or qualified council
§Y*§! Bureaucratic reforms
Palace bureaucracy can be §Rdecreased§! by:
§Y*§! Having unqualified lords
§Y*§! Having a weak or unqualified council
§Y*§! Succession
This character has sold bureaucratic positions, a sign that corruption has taken hold in their realm.
Due to poor recordkeeping, inefficient administrative oversight, and corrupt palace bureaucrats, this realm's bureaucracy is in complete disarray.
The place is full of good and loyal palace bureaucrats that maintain the bureaucracy needed to steer the realm to prosperity, making it the envy of lesser kings.
This character has requested a personal tribute from his realm.
The results of your reforms will be apparent in six months
Alloted a small budget to enact reforms.
Grant a fair budget to spur reform.
Pump a lot of gold into lavishly reforming the palace.
This character's attempt to reform their realm has gone poorly.
The reform attempts of this character have been a success.

Militarization measures how military-oriented a realm is. As it ebbs and flows, the efficiency and size of your military will move with it. Additionally, being a militarized state harms palace bureaucracy, so it is wise to balance both bureaucratic norms and militarization.
Militarization can be §Gincreased§! by:
§Y*§! Having strong lords
§Y*§! Having qualified marshals and commanders
§Y*§! Winning major battles
Militarization can be §Rdecreased§! by:
§Y*§! Having weak lords
§Y*§! Having weak marshals and commanders
§Y*§! Bureaucratic Reforms
§Y*§! Losing major battles
The Militarization of the Realm is currently minimal
The Militarization of the Realm is currently substantial

This character is devoted to Tarhunna
This character is devoted to Arinniti

This character is devoted to Sabázios

This character is devoted to Derzelas

This character is syncretic with with those of the [hellenic.GetName] Pantheon, and may interact with the gods Zeus, Ares, Athenâ, Demeter, Apollon, Hermes, and Aphrodite.
This character is syncretic with with those of the [european_group.GetName] Pantheon, and may interact with the gods Sabázios, Pleistoros, Derzelas, and Kubeleya.
This character is a Stratocratic ruler
This Hero has made a name for themselves among their people!
Has not recieved a boon from the gods
The Chief of the Royal Bodyguards is responsible for procuring and administrating the royal guards, having immense control over the livelihood of the great king.
The Chief of the Palace Servants oversees the servants of the royal palace, and is in regular contact with those close to the great king and with the great king themselves.

The Chief of the Storehouse is responsible for one of the most important facets of a civilization - grain storage. Keeping track of the in and outflow of grain is both a difficult and prestigious job.

The Chief of the Scribes is one of the most prestigious titles in an empire. As the overseer of all scribes in the land, the Chief of the Scribes is responsible for imperial transactions and recordkeeping.
Chief of the Wooden Tablet Scribes

Since a hegemon has a wide array of responsibilities, it is advantageous for a ruler to allow a close relative to be co-monarch, both allowing the relative to gain experience and the hegemon to relieve some of their duties.
Originally belonging to Akhilleus' father Peleus, it was forged by Haphaistos as a wedding present.
This set of armor was forged after Akhilleus lost his original set after Pátroklos died at the hands of Hektor.
Forged by Haphaistos after Pátroklos was killed, this shield is wrought many intricate designs.
Sent directly by the gods, it is said that this sword has magical properties.
Originally belonging to the famed archer King Eurutos of Oikhalía, it was passed on to his son Iphitos, and then to the Odusseús during his journey to Messenia.
Dipped in the poisonous blood of the Lérne Húdra, a single scratch from its point is enough to kill a man.
Made of bronze and seven layers of ox-hide, this shield forged for Aías, son of Telamon provides excellent defense against any foe.
This beautifully crafted piece of ivory was fashioned by Demeter as a replacement for Pelops' shoulder, which was accidently eaten when his father Tantalos served him to the gods.
This wooden statue of Pallas Athena protects Troy from destruction as long as it is within its walls.
The divine scepter of the House of dark-faced Pelops. Haphaistos gave it to Zeus, Zeus gave it to Hermes, and Hermes gave it to Pelops.
A helmet made from slivers of boar tusks attached to a padded leather base. Dozens of boars were slain to make this savage piece of armor.
This lion-pelt was taken as a trophy from some unlucky lion. Wearing it almost fills one with courage, as if the spirit of the beast itself enters the wearer...
As an [Root.Culture.GetName], you must matrilineally wed another [Root.Culture.GetName].
As an [Root.Culture.GetName], you can matrilineally wed one of your [Root.Culture.GetName] dependents to another [Root.Culture.GetName].
Has same culture as capital of the title
